review.title: Rooting opinions in the minds: a cognitive model and a formal account of opinions and their dynamics
review.abstract: The study of opinions, their formation and change, is one of the defining topics addressed by social psychology, but in recent years other disciplines, like computer science and complexity, have tried to deal with this issue. Despite the flourishing of different models and theories in both fields, several key questions still remain unanswered. The understanding of how opinions change and the way they are affected by social influence are challenging issues requiring a thorough analysis of opinion per se but also of the way in which they travel between agents' minds and are modulated by these exchanges. To account for the two-faceted nature of opinions, which are mental entities undergoing complex social processes, we outline a preliminary model in which a cognitive theory of opinions is put forward and it is paired with a formal description of them and of their spreading among minds. Furthermore, investigating social influence also implies the necessity to account for the way in which people change their minds, as a consequence of interacting with other people, and the need to explain the higher or lower persistence of such changes.

metadata.title: Rooting opinions in the minds: a cognitive model and a formal account of opinions and their dynamics

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to determine for themselves what they want to do and what they want to do.

sections.heading: 2 State of the Art
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able are able to determine for themselves what they want and what they want to do.

sections.heading: 2.1 Main Advances
sections.text: This paper aims to outline a non-reductionist cognitive model of opinions and their dynamics. In contrast to the models discussed above, we first offer a definition of opinions as mental representations that have specific characteristics that make their revision and actualization more or less easy and permanent. In addition, grounding of opinions in the minds allows to take into account not only direct revision processes triggered by comparison with other opinions, i.e. social influences, but also revisions based on changes in other mental representations that support this opinion. The computer model presented in this paper aims to provide a preliminary unifying framework for defining opinions and characterizing their dynamics in a simple but non-reductionist approach. Opinions in several models of opinion dynamics are regarded as changes depending on social influence, we try to outline what social influence is and how the social network structure affects the opinions of the actors.

sections.heading: 3 A Cognitive Theory of Opinions
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to determine for themselves what they want to do and what they want to do.

sections.heading: 4 Toward a Formal Definition
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Preliminaries
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1.1 Time Varying Graphs
sections.text: The temporal aspects of our model of opinion are based on Time-Varying Graphs (TVG) formalism, a general mathematical framework [8] designed to deal with the temporal dimension of networked data and express its dynamics from an interaction-centric point of view [26]. Let us consider a series of units V (or nodes), a series of relationships E between these units (edges), and an alphabet L that takes into account any property that might have (label) a relationship; that is, E V · V · L. L can contain multi-value elements. It is assumed that the relationships (interactions) between units take place over a time dimension (continuous or discrete) T of the lifespan of the system, which is generally a subset of N (discrete time systems) or R (continuous time systems). The dynamics of the system can then be described by a time-varying graph or TVG, G = (V, E, T), where a single date or continuity system (R) is present.

sections.heading: 4.1.2 The underlying graph
sections.text: Considering a TVG = (V, E, T, м), the graph G = (V, E) is referred to as the underlying graph of G. This static graph should be considered as a kind of footprint of G, flattening the time dimension and indicating only the pairs of nodes that have relationships at a certain time in a certain time interval. In most studies and applications, it is assumed that G is connected; in general, this is not necessarily the case. Note that the connectivity of G = (V, E) does not imply that G is connected at a certain time; in fact, G could be disconnected at any time.

sections.heading: 4.1.3 Edge-centric evolution
sections.text: From the point of view of the edge (relationships within epistemic representations), the evolution of variations in availability is derived. TVG defines the available data of an edge e, noted I (e), as the union of all data at which the edge is available, i.e. I (e) = {t тT: ρ (e, t) = 1}. In the case of a multi-interval of availability I (e) = {[t1, t2) с [t3, t4)...}, the sequence of data t1, t3,... is called the appearance data of e, notes app (e), and the sequence of data t2, t4,... is called disappearance data of e, notes Dis (e). Finally, the sequence t1, t2, t3,... is called the characteristic data of e, notes ST (e).

sections.heading: 4.1.4 Graph-centric evolution
sections.text: From a global point of view, the evolution of the system can be derived from a sequence of (static) graphs SG = G1, G2.., each Gi corresponding to a static snapshot of G, so that e-EGi [ti, ti + 1) (e) = 1, with two possible meanings for tis: either the sequence of tis is a discretization of time (e.g. ti = i); or it corresponds to the sequence of certain data when topological events occur in the graph, where this sequence corresponds to the sorting (ю {ST (e): e-E}). In the latter case, the sequence is called characteristic data of G and ST (G) is noted.

sections.heading: 4.2 Modeling Epistemic Representations
sections.text: An opinion is an epistemic representation of a state of the world in relation to a given object p.Formally we can state the following: Definition 1 is an epistemic representation of a state of the world m еM is a quadruple p, To, Ts, dc defined by a preposition p in relation to a given object O and two variable To and Ts defined in R. By varying the dimensions of the range To and Ts we can define a taxonomy of the epistemic value of an information, namely the objective truth value, the perceived truth values and the degree of trust in relation to the preposition p.By varying the dimensions of the range To and Ts we can define a taxonomy of the epistemic value of an information, namely the objective truth value, the perceived truth values and the degree of trust in relation to the preposition p.By varying the dimensions of the range To and Ts, we can define a taxonomy of the epistemic value of the information, namely the objective truth value, the perceived truth values and the degree of trust in relation to the preposition p.By varying the dimensions of the range To and Ts we can define a taxonomy of the range of the epistemic value of an information, namely the degree of the perceived truth value and the degree of trust in relation to the preposition p.By varying the range To and Ts, we can define a taxonomy of the epistemic value of the information, namely the objective truth value, the perceived truth values and the degree of the preposition p.By varying the dimensions of the range To and Ts, we can define a taxonomy of the epistemic value of an <

sections.heading: 4.3 Opinions and Individuals
sections.text: We can define an epistemic representation graph as a network of epistemic representation immersed in a dynamic network (at a given time interval and the linkages indicate the correlation between them. Consider a set of V mental representation (or nodes) that interacts with each other over time. Any relationship between mental representation can be formalized by a quadruplet. (Any relationship between mental representation can be expressed by a quadruplet c = {u, v, t1, t2}, where u and v are the mental representations involved (either beliefs, knowledge, or opinions). (t1) is the time in which the correlation occurs, and t2 is the time in which the relationship ends. (A given pair of nodes can, of course, be subject to several such interactions (and, for generality, we allow these interactions to overlap). (In the face of a time interval T = ta, tb) T (where tb) and tb (where tb) can be either a tval and T (where tta b), and tta (where T) interval b).

sections.heading: 4.4 Opinion Dynamics and Society
sections.text: One of the most famous formalities aimed at describing the conviction process is the "Bounded Confidence Model" (BCM), in which agents exchanging information are modeled in such a way that they only adjust their opinions if the preceding and received information are close enough to each other. Such an aspect is modeled by the introduction of a real number that stands for tolerance or uncertainty, so that an agent with Opinion x interacts only with agents whose opinions are interval x, x +. Such a model does not provide an explanation for the broad, massive and disciplinary use of the BCM ([18, 14]), ranging from "viral marketing" to the distortions of opinion played by the Italians through controlled mass media (24, 4, 5, 14]). Such a model does not provide an explanation for the phenomena that lead to the tolerance value, it is simply assumed to be considered static value. In this work, we will sketch out the factors that influence the acceptance or rejection of others.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: In this preparatory work, we have tried to design a cognitively based dynamic opinion model, in which we defined these mental representations as carachterized by the presence of three specific characteristics. In contrast to psychological theories of opinions, which usually provide rich definitions that are too complex to reduce to measurable variables, we have isolated three essential constitutive elements that characterize this type of mental representation. On the other hand, we have tried to overcome the reductionist approach of opinion-dynamic models, in which the wealth of human cognitive processes is replaced by easily calculable factors that have little to do with actual human behavior. Therefore, we have proposed to apply time-varying diagrams in order to develop a formal model that is capable of taking into account the way opinions are generated and changed depending on the presence and opinions of other actors in the network. We are fully aware of the complexity of this problem, and this work represents a preliminary attempt to merge cognitive opinions with a narrow cognitive approach.

sections.heading: 6 Acknowledgments
sections.text: We thank two anonymous referees for their useful comments and participants of the workshop on gossip and opinions (Rome, June 2010, ISTC CNR), and special thanks to Isabella Poggi and Cristiano Castelfranchi for their comments.

In general, opinions are treated as synonyms for different mental objects, as beliefs [20], or more frequently, attitudes.
Opinions are often conceptualized as attitudes [19], [15], [21] or they are used as interchangeable terms that have in common the fact of being affected by social influence and persuasion [25].

Allport [3] recognizes the difference between attitudes and opinions but he nonetheless considers the measurement of opinions as one way of identifying the strength and value of personal attitudes.
An alternative view contrasts the affective content of attitudes with the more cognitive quality of opinions that involve some kind of conscious judgements [12].
Crespi [9] considers individual opinions as ”judgemental outcomes of an individual’s transactions with the surrounding world”
As other authors already pointed out [1], many models of opinion and social influence do not provide careful definitions of what an opinion is and how it is affected by social influence.
This happens to be true also for theories of persuasion, like the social impact theory [16], a static theory of how social processes operate at the level of the individual at a given point in time.
Part of this theory has been developed usign computational modeling by Nowak, Szamrej and Latan [2].
